Tables 4 and 5 break down the volume metrics by source and language.
Even for the 5% objective (the nearest to the current 3.39% shown in Table 4), it does not seem practical to gather 3.77E+13 characters (≈\approx≈ 37 TeraBytes) of text in a short notice, to verify this projection.
But the projection is still verifiable on the total number of arXiv characters ingested. From Table 4 for 80,399,442,210 text characters:
On Table 10 we compare the full arXiv metrics (already displayed on Table 4) to the same metrics using only validated sentences.

S6.T9.1.caption: arXiv projections for %d.sentences with repetitions vs #text characters.
S6.T9.1.table:
%d.sentence with repetitions 5.00% 25.00% 50.00% 75.00% 100.00%
#text characters 3.77E+13 9.81E+48 1.82E+93 3.39E+137 6.29E+181
references:
Using the trend line for extrapolation, (assuming that the trend line would not change the type of curve), Table 9 shows the projected #text characters that would be required to achieve the desired %d.sentences with repetitions.
Projections for higher %d.sentence with repetitions (25%, 50%, 75% and 100%) are also shown in table 9 for curiosity, and should not be taken very seriously, as it is well known that for a logarithmic curve, small variations on the curve coefficient will cause large changes for distant points. These projections also assume that curve does not change shape.
